page.title: 17Wytham and the Thames
page.content: The Seacourt stream links Wytham to the river Thames. The 144 mile-long river winds from the west through the flat, cultivated farmland that surrounds the village, and is controlled by local locks and weirs. The flow of the river can vary from 3-8 knots at this point. Each year the river floods and there are as many as 4 drownings recorded in that time. At and above Wytham the locks are beam locks and are operated by lock keepers who work from 9 a.m. - 7 p.m, six days a week. The families of the lock keepers enjoy the peaceful, rural life along the river. Links with the village prevent them feeling too isolated in the Victorian stone houses. The Thames is much used for leisure and the lock keepers' lives are busy ones, particularly from April to October.
